subject: Business
title: How Insurance Actually Works
description: A micro-lesson that makes How Insurance Actually Works usable.

hook.text: 1,000 people each pay $1,000 a year for fire insurance. Ten houses burn down. Each gets $100,000. The math works.

buildup.text: Insurance pools risk: many people pay small premiums so the few who suffer losses get large payouts.

discovery.text: Insurers profit because they collect more in premiums than they pay in claims, plus invest the float.

twist.text: Insurance is a bad deal on average â€” you pay more than you'll likely receive. But it prevents catastrophic ruin.

climax.text: Warren Buffett built Berkshire Hathaway's empire by investing insurance float.

punchline.text: Insurance isn't about winning. It's about not losing everything.

quiz.question: Why is insurance a 'bad deal' on average but still worth buying?
options: You'll likely pay more than you receive, but it prevents catastrophic financial ruin
Insurance companies always pay more than they collect
Insurance is only valuable for wealthy individuals
